definition: Agent Communication Protocol, a structured approach for message exchange between autonomous systems with predictable schemas and transport semantics.
An autonomous software entity that can interpret goals, reason over context, and take actions using tools and workflows.
A machine-readable profile describing an agent's capabilities, interfaces, constraints, and metadata for discovery and trust.
The degree to which an agent can decide and execute actions without requiring constant human confirmation.
An internal reasoning process an LLM may use to arrive at an answer; typically kept private while exposing concise rationale.
The maximum amount of input and generated tokens an LLM can process in a single interaction cycle.
The mechanism by which agents find tools, services, and other agents through metadata, registries, or protocol introspection.
A dense vector representation of text or data used for semantic search, retrieval, clustering, and similarity scoring.
A repeatable test system for scoring agent behavior against predefined tasks, metrics, and expected outcomes.
A model capability for emitting structured arguments that map to executable tools, APIs, or internal functions.
A routing and policy layer that brokers traffic between agents, users, and external systems with auth and rate limits.
Safety, policy, and quality controls that constrain or validate model and agent actions before execution.
An operating pattern where critical or high-risk actions require explicit human approval before completion.
A verifiable representation of an agent, user, or system principal used for authentication, authorization, and auditing.
The ability of heterogeneous agent stacks and tools to work together through shared protocols and data contracts.
A security principle where each agent or tool is granted only the minimum permissions needed to perform tasks.
Model Context Protocol, a standard interface for connecting models and agents to external data sources and tools.
Persisted or transient state that allows an agent to retain context, preferences, and prior outcomes across interactions.
Instrumentation for tracing, logging, and measuring agent behavior to diagnose quality, latency, and reliability issues.
The coordination of multiple agents, tools, and workflow steps to achieve complex goals with dependency control.
Runtime application of organizational rules governing data access, action permissions, compliance, and approvals.
Designing prompts, constraints, and examples to shape model outputs for reliability, relevance, and tool correctness.
A security attack where malicious instructions are inserted into model inputs to override intended behavior or exfiltrate data.
Retrieval-Augmented Generation, a pattern that combines model inference with external retrieval to improve factual grounding.
An iterative reasoning pattern where an agent critiques and improves its own outputs before finalizing an action.
Re-running known scenarios to ensure model updates, prompt changes, or infrastructure modifications do not degrade behavior.
A canonical directory for publishing and discovering agent capabilities, schemas, endpoints, and trust metadata.
Executing code or tools in isolated environments to limit blast radius, protect secrets, and contain unsafe behavior.
Checking structured inputs and outputs against a strict schema to prevent malformed tool invocations and runtime faults.
Breaking complex objectives into smaller ordered subtasks that can be solved by one or more agents.
The planned allocation of input and output tokens used to control cost, latency, and model context usage.
The execution pattern where an agent selects and invokes external tools based on intent, context, and schema constraints.
A storage engine optimized for high-dimensional similarity search, commonly used to power semantic retrieval for agents.
A defined sequence of states and operations that coordinates decisions, tool use, retries, and outputs toward a goal.
A security model that continuously verifies identity and context rather than assuming trust based on network location.
